page.title: 11Crops in Bourtie/Keithall
page.content: Land over 500 feet within the parishes of Bourtie, Keithall and Kinkell includes Hilbrae, Pitgaveny and the Hill of Crimond. Here farmers qualify for a hillfarm subsidy an use the land predominantly for the grazing of sheep, although some cattle are also grazed. The animals find grass between natural stands of gorse and broom and intermittent scrub birch, ash and gean (wild cherry). On the lower pastures the largest crops are winter-worn barley and grass for silage. There are, however, smaller harvests of winter wheat, spring barley, some oats and some turnip for cattle feed. Many grain crops are udersown with grass, so that cattle may us the fields after the main crop has been harvested. Sheep are left out all year round, but cattle are kept inside in byres between mid Nov-April.
